reviewText: I've just given away ----- try doing THIS! ----- about a thousand VHS-video-cassette tapes; hated to THROW themaway.In the process, getting rid of a number of TIME TRAVEL videos ----- still ----- not on DVD/BDs.I bought this one and another favorite (UNIDENTIFIED FLYING ODDBALL) at prices I couldn't say "No!" to.My wife watched one of the episodes with me. I told her it was a shame that the lead actor, Jon-Erik Hexum, diedin a [dumb] freak accident. He didn't know that the WAD at the end of a "blank" pistol cartridge WILL kill you atas close as six-feet... even IF you were just pretending to shoot yourself for a dumb prank.Speaking of DUMB, while I love ALL time travel programs/movies, it often irks me, that a time travel movie has allthe ancient people's languages be modern-English --- yeah, I know, for convenience --- inThe Time Tunnel,Hebrew, Greek, German, Chinese was NO problem either.I live in Germany. NOT conversant in the language, the last time someone said"You have lived in Germany for twenty-years now; how's your GERMAN?"Naturally, I replied with "SHE'S fine! SHE's at work right now."HIGHLY recommended to TIME TRAVEL fans! Check LOGIC at the door. It's a KID's show [for adults]. Each episodeends with a slightly different epilogue, such as, "Go to YOUR library and learn more about Cleopatra and George Herman"Babe" Ruth!"

reviewText: Man, this is some good viewing. No foul language, no explicit sex, and no spoiled, bratty, self-centered, disrespectful children. I can sit down with my children and enjoy this series with out fear of some hidden agenda being forced on them or exposing them to some other Hollywood filth that is so prevalent in today's media. It is a little corny, as was all the 80's series but well worth buying. We sat down one Saturday morning and watched the first two DVD's straight through, Bogg seems to get all the fair maidens to fall for him and every episode has him kissing at least one of them...a little much but not graphic, just silly. Jeff gets a little whiney in some episodes. If you watch the series straight through, it gets a little old. I suggest taking a break between DVD's, it gives you time to forget his whininess. The series is good stuff!

reviewText: In 1982, while this show aired, I was six, turning seven during its run.While it only lasted 20 episodes and was bumped by the World Series too often, I was glued to the television whenever it was on.The lead actor was a rare thing in those days.  He was a true athlete, not some skinny twerp pretending to be a tough guy.  He could act.  He appealed to all ages and genders for different reasons: ladies like the pretty-boy aspect, guys liked the tough guy thing, little boys knew he'd always save the kid from trouble.  While the actor died of a tragic accident, he left a short, but impressive legacy in his role as Phinneas Bog.The kid was a touch hammy, but often true to form for child actors of the era.  The difference here was the show's writers played to his strengths and it showed.  He complemented his on-screen buddy well.The shows did its best stab at history, made it exciting, and ended each episode with a "if you want to learn more, it's all in books, at your public library."Quantum Leap never would have happened without this show where the characters fixed things that went wrong with time...
Title: N/A

reviewText: I had been looking for "Voyagers" for several years to become available on DVD.  I had not seen the series since it originally aired in the early 1980's.  This is a cool show with educational value.  It is pre-"Back to the Future" by a few years.  Good stuff!  Sadly the series did not last long, thus they were able to put all of the episodes in this 1 set for the show's 25th anniversary (1982 - 2007).  I highly recommend this DVD set.  Unfortunately it is not in a book or at my local library.  Bats breath!!!

reviewText: This was a family series I would recommend to everyone with children (or not).Every episode is a learning experience in history that always ends with encouragement (from Meeno Peluce) to go to the library to learn more.It's a very funny and heartwarming story of an orphan (Meeno Peluce) that, by mistake, goes on a voyage through time with Phineas Bogg (played by Jon-Erik Hexum). They correct mistakes in history  to make sure it comes out the way it should, with lots of drama and comedy along the way.It really can interest your children in history!!! A lot of children got better grades in history during the short time this series was on the air.....Watch It!

reviewText: We travel through time to help history along;Give it a push when it's needed.When the omni's red, it means history's wrong.Our job is to get everything back on track.Green light, kid: We did it!This show is as much fun to watch as it was 30 years ago when I saw it brand new.....  The acting is really superb in this... Jon Erik Hexum's first acting to a TV audience, had natural, inate acting abilities... He was learning about Hollywood and showbiz after only moving out to Hollywood I think 3 months earlier and cast in a primetime series..... We lost out on a geat actor, who died way, way to early in '84, but perhaps he is a time traveler for real, and he was just visiting us for 2 brief years in Tinseltown.  and this is one of the treasures he left long after he left us in 1984.  The transfer is very good.  No commerical breaks, like when originally run.Go get it. Before they sell out.
summary: pure entertainment, educational, and also a trip back time for me
Title: N/A

reviewText: This series was a fond memory of my childhood. I love the premise and the two main actors were great. I didn't even mind that I may be learning something about history in the process. Truly one short lived show. Should have lasted longer so it could develop more. Seems to me that any type of show that is both action/adventure but also teaches you something always gets passed over. I wonder if this is more an issue with the executives than the fans. Remember the Young Indiana Jones Chronicles? TV can be educational and fun as this show proved. Aside from a few saturday morning shows, there was little on tv that had much to offer that didn't talk down to kids. This show seemed like it was aimed at kids and adults. One thing I thought that it showed was that kids have something to offer if adults would just listen. Though Boggs was the one in charge of the time travel it was the kid who had a lot of the answers. So they benefited each other very well. Anyway this is a great dvd to buy to watch and have fun If I were the history channel (which I love) I would try to include this in my lineup because it shows how learning history can be fun and addictive. Just wanted to add also that Hexum died on the set of Cover Up which took place after this series. I think they needed to keep Voyagers on a lot longer.The show, just like the actor, left us way too soon.
summary: How dare they try to teach me something:)

reviewText: This was a great show I remember from my childhood and it still holds up fairly well today despite some cheesy acting at times and fake-looking Hollywood sets. It is good clean fun with adventure and some humor all mixed together and topped off with Jon-Erik Hexum's hunky good looks. The only real problem is that it makes me sad that this actor never got the chance to really further his career due to his sudden and sad death at such an early age. Maybe if this show had not been cancelled he would not have had the tragic accident that took his life while filming his next show. Anyway, these episodes of Voyagers are fun to watch and interesting. I found them to be amusing because you get the fun adventures while learning about history. I've always thought the concept of time travel was cool and this is sort of a Bill & Ted's Excellent Adventure of TV. The only thing that bothered me was that Jeffrey and Phineas always wore the same clothes in every episode. Didn't they ever stop to get new threads? As far as rating this dvd set, it would have been nice to have some bonus features- interviews with the cast or commentaries etc- but this contains none. All you get are the episodes. But they are worth it...
summary: Too bad they don't make shows like this anymore!
Title: N/A

reviewText: I shamelessly admit that my original reason for watching the series was the good looks of actor Jon-Erik Hexum.  But I soon got caught up in the idea of this smart, personable kid who has to tell the professional who someone is and what needs to happen in history as they pop in and out of situations gone awry.  Nostalgia had me getting the DVD set, but after viewing these episodes again I realized this is a great way for kids to get enthused about history.  The end of each episode even encourages you to go to your local library to learn more.In each episode the duo generally take on two problems in history, often filled with action and danger.  You learn something about famous history figures in different times and places in the world.Jeffrey Jones, the twelve year-old kid, had recently been orphaned and overhears his aunt and uncle arguing about being forced to take him on.  Phineas Bogg, the Voyager, crashes into the kid's bedroom by mistake.  Jeff ends up falling out of a window and Phineas dives after him to use the Omni, the time travel device, to get them out of there before they hit the ground.  He's unable to get Jeff back to his own time.  Unfortunately Bogg loses his book telling him what needs to take place in history.  But Jeff's father had been a history professor and Jeff knows his stuff, making him an important partner in Bogg's job.Ok, their are lots of explosions and some are reused in different episodes.  And if you pay attention you'll recognize some locations being reused with different props to give it a different time period, but hey, this was filmed at Universal Studios.  I highly recommend this for kids.  If only history was made this fun in school.  I gave it to my nine year-old nephew for Christmas.  It was a hit.

reviewText: Just imagine a sci-fi fantasy television series geared towards children that would introduce them to extraordinary individuals and monumental events throughout world history.  Yet, something is wrong - history isn't following its intended course, as, for instance, the Germans are winning World War I handily because they invented the airplane first (after the Wright Brothers had broken up in Dayton, OH, before completing their famous collaboration at Kitty Hawk, NC).  Enter the Voyagers: time travelers criss-crossing the space-time continuum righting historical inaccuracies and ensuring that history unfolds as truly intended.In late 1982, Universal Studios and Scholastic Books produced this inventive, albeit short-lived Sunday night adventure featuring the late Jon-Erik Hexum as the swashbuckling, impetuous Phineas Bogg and Meeno Peluce as his young sidekick, Jeffrey Jones (a historical whiz).  Thrown together by a fluke meeting at Jeffrey's home in 1982, Bogg, whose brash courage often overrides his lack of historical knowledge, must now rely on an 11-year old orphan to keep his job since his trusty Voyager guidebook was left behind in the jaws of Jeffrey's dog, Ralph.  Worse yet, Bogg's time-traveling device, the Omni (similar to a gold-plated pocket watch), is designed only to go up to 1970, so there is no way of Bogg returning Jeffrey to his proper time.  Hence, the series is set for Bogg and Jeffrey to zip back and forth through time for 20 episodes typically correcting wrongs in two different time periods per episode.  Exemplified in several solid episodes, the cause-and-effect significance in world history should prove fascinating to a new generation of young fans watching this DVD set.Overall, this exuberant series still performs exceptionally well after nearly thirty years.  Despite being a 25-year old rookie actor, Hexum gave an excellent performance as the heroic lead next to the scene-stealing Peluce (a TV veteran at his young age).  Their on-screen chemistry, I think, remains the program's strongest asset, in addition to its adherence to at least fairly accurate portrayals of major historical figures ranging from Thomas Edison to Cleopatra to Babe Ruth to Abraham Lincoln, among numerous others.  For instance, how many television programs can coherently juggle a storyline with infant Moses, the Wright Brothers, Eddie Rickenbacker vs. the Red Baron, and Hollywood actress Mary Pickford in its pilot episode alone?  "Voyagers!" managed to do it for one season in an era in which inspired prime-time children's programming was most uncommon.What I really believe endures about "Voyagers!" is the maturing father-son relationship between Bogg and Jeffrey, as Bogg (despite his dislike of children) begrudgingly grants Jeffrey's wish for a surrogate father.  Evidence of this ongoing sub-plot is readily seen in the poignant Christmas episode entitled "Merry Christmas, Bogg," where Bogg tries to leave a disgruntled Jeffrey with his early 20th Century ancestors thinking the boy is ultimately better off with family than time-traveling without a home.  Further evidence of their growing friendship appears in "The Trial of Phineas Bogg," as Bogg's superiors put him on trial for committing multiple offenses against the strict Voyager Code.  As hints of Jeffrey's destiny are revealed, the episode (perhaps the series' best) would have worked quite well as its finale.  Instead, a sequel to this episode featuring Jack the Ripper (entitled "Jack's Back") is the last one, which originally aired in mid-1983.For what it is worth, I highly recommend purchasing "Voyagers! The Complete Series" as a terrific means of introducing your young children to the (pardon the expression) timeless magic and wonders of history, let alone other fascinating books they may yet find at the local library.It's an excellent investment for ages 8 and up.Rating: 10/10.P.S.  You can also find for a low cost on Amazon.com the long out-of-print Scholastic adaptation by Joe Claro of the series' premiere episode.  I certainly recommend it for second graders and up.
summary: Voyagers!: The Timeless Adventures of Phineas Bogg and Jeffrey Jones

reviewText: Yep!  I was there in 1982, watching this on TV.  I loved this show then and was happy to see it come out on DVD.  The older guy/John Erik-Hexum is a time-traveler.  His job is to pop in and out of history and tweak things that are not exactly right, so they can happen the way they are supposed to.  I don't remember them ever explaining WHY they needed tweaking when they already happened once.  While I'm sure it must be the "overlapping time & space/there is no linear time theory," I don't think they ever actually SAID it. Anyway, John pops into current times (with a bang) into this young boy's (age 10/12?)room (actually hanging out his window).  In all the excitement, the boy's dog grabs the guide book and John and the boy fall out the window. To keep from dying in the fall, John leaps them into another time and place.  The problem is, that John needs the guide book to navigate around and no longer has it.  John doesn't really know history either, but the boy's father was a history buff or teacher, so the boy knows all about what actually happened in history when they pop in and out of the different time periods.  They keep popping around history, fixing things that went astray, and trying to get the boy back to current times.It's a neat show for the action as well as for the history lessons that you get.  Although the show seemed to be quite successful, a tragic accident while filming took the life of John, which is why he quickly disappeared from sight.  Still, there are a lot of good episodes here.  The show does not need an end.  It's a series of adventures.

reviewText: This is a blast from the past from 25 years ago--I remember it very fondly!  Phineas Bogg is a Voyager--a person who is supposed to travel through time and give history a push from time to time so that the proper things take place.  The machine that he uses malfunctions a lot, he doesn't have a lot of knowledege about history, and he accidentally ends up in the bedroom of a boy named Jeffrey Jones in 1982, an orphan who knows a lot about history.  He ends up traveling with Bogg, going from one adventure to the next.  Not as heavy handed and preachy as Quantum Leap (which I loved, too)--a fun series, great family entertainment, kids should like it.One thing I remember is that whenever Meeno and Jon-Erik did interviews, they always spoke as if they were an equal team.  Jon-Erik never spoke of Meeno as just a kid.  On screen, they had a very nice relationship.  The kid's cute, the guy's hunky, and the adventures are fun.Generally in each episode, the voyagers drop into one scenario, leave at the first commercial break to another, solve the second problem, then take knowledge from that second scenario back to the first to solve the initial problem.  Some of the links are that of situations (Spartacus and Tubbman have slavery in common), and others involve learning a trick to get out of the first (Salem and Houdini)Here are the episodes--title and topic:Pilot--Time Traveler and orphan meetCreated Equal (Spartacus and Harriet Tubman)Bully and Billy (Teddy Roosevelt and Billy the Kid)Agents of Satan (Salem witch trials and Harry Houdini)Worlds Apart (Lawrence of Arabia and Thomas Edison)Cleo and the Babe (Cleopatra is brought to 1920s New York/Lucy Luciano)The Day the Rebs took Lincoln (Civil War and London/Dickens)Old Hickory and the Pirate (War of 1812/New Orleans)The Travels of Marco Polo...and Friends (1930s New York/Isaac Wolfstein)An Arrow Pointing East (Lindburgh then Robin Hood)Merry Christmas, Bogg (George Washington then Samuel Gompers)Buffalo Bill and Annie Oakely Play the Palace (Queen Victoria)The Trial of Phineas Bogg (Bogg is on trial back home)Sneak Attack (Pearl Harbor plus young Bill Cody/Pony Express)Voyagers of the Titanic (plus rabies and Pasteur)Pursuit (WWII/Werner von Braun)Destiny's Choice (FDR in 1924 Hollywood)All Fall Down (1938, boxing, Joe Louis)Barrier's of Sound (1890s Texas, Ike's mom)Jack's Back (Jack the Ripper)Some guest stars:  Ed Begley, Jr., Gregory Itzin (twice!), Lance LeGault, Tricia O'Neil, Michael Fox (the reason M. J. Fox had to add the J?), Jonathan Frakes, Anne Lockhart, Dana Elcar, Frank Marth, and Julia Duffy.

reviewText: The show we fondly remember with Meeno Peluce as Jeff the "smart-kid" who listened in school and the well-intentioned but historically inept Bogg played by the late Jon-Erik Hexum. Jeff serves as their only guide through time, fixing history. Much like the "Magic Tree House" series serves today as an elementary students overview of pop history, Voyagers! is flashing or particularly clever, but it remains surprisingly "timely" in the family-sci-fi genre. The music may be as over-the-top as some of the dialogue, at times formulaic, over all, still a great show.We've got a green light, kids!
summary: Voyagers on DVD! Somewhere an OMNI has gone GREEN

reviewText: This is a good clean adventure series.  This is a fun way to learn some history, and stimulate the imagination.  Phineas Bogg and Jefferey Jonees exemplify what true teamwork is, something everyone needs to sharpen on.  There are morals to the stories as well.  If you have kids, watch this with them.  I do not have any so I cannot comment on kids' thoughts.  Anway, I was only 10 years old when this came out, but I do not recall watching it.  What got me to learn about this was my interest to find out who the handsome actor was that I saw on a game show years ago, and one episode I managed to stay up to watch - Cover Up.  I not only could somewhat recall Jon-Erik's handsome face, but I also recalled the catchy song Holding Out For A Hero.  Shortly later, as an 11 year old I devastatingly learned about his accident.  I could only remember a very handsome man with a name containing two names separated with a -.  Thanks for the internet, when I searched the song Holding Out For A Hero, some peoples' comments lead me to learn Jon-Erik's name, and that he also starred in the Voyagers.  After reading the reviews, and my love to see him again I placed my order.

reviewText: I was 4 or 5 when this show was originally on.  I didn't discover it until my senior year in high school, when Sci-Fi channel aired the series.  I instantly fell in love.  I love history, so the different twists on historical events that needed to be fixed were really fun to watch.  Sure, there were some really cheesy moments and lines, but a 12 year old outsmarting an adult, and of course Jon-Erik Hexum's good looks made it a favorite.When I found out the series was on DVD, you bet I ordered it!The best part about the series is it encourages kids to learn more about the people and events showcased through the episodes.  You don't see any family shows today encouraging kids to "go to your local library and check out a book to learn more about Pearl Harbor."  Instead, the family shows nowadays feature selfish teens, clueless and/or annoying parents, and promote bad behavior (Mommy, I love Miley's boots!  I want a pair just like them if they are in my size!"  Yeah right, princess, Mommy cannot afford $200 for a pair of high-heeled stiletto boots!  "But Mommy, one of my friends said her mommy's going to get her a pair!  You're a meanie!"--  I'm sure I've got this to look forward to...)That little rant about today's family programming aside, This series is a way to bring life to history.  Kids are learning less and less about history (as it's not an important school subject and is usually not included in state standardized testing).  Encourage your kids to learn, and even ask them "What do you think could have caused this to go wrong?"  I just wish I could give it more stars!

reviewText: This is a beloved show from my childhood. I remember watching it every week, and not missing an episode!  The plot was very interesting. Bogg (a Voyager) and a boy "traveled through time to help history along, give it a push when needed." They have a pocket watch type of thing called an Omni. When the Omni flashed red, history was wrong. When they fixed history and put it like it should be, the Omni flashed Green.Bogg was a pirate who was then made a Voyager. By mistake, he was transported to 1982 (the Omni should only go ti the early 1970's. Another mishap happens and Bogg takes the boy (Jeffery) with him, who is an orphan and is living with his aunt and uncle who don't really want him, and they travel through history.  If you want to find out what the mishap was, then you need to get the series.As I said, they travel through history and have to fix it. The adventures lead Bogg and Jeffery to all sorts of historical events. Some of the historical events are: The Salem Witch Trials, The Revolutionary War where the British win, the Civil War, where the South wins, helping out in fighting slavery, Billy the Kid, Moses, Gladiators, Babe Ruth, and much, much more.The costumes in Voyager! are fantastic! They are period correct, and just adds so much to the series. The music is also period correct.I also loved at the end of every episode Jeffery does a voice over, "If you want to learn more about *insert episode adventure here, i.e Civil War, Babe Ruth, ect) then take a voyage to your local library, it's all in books."  The show encourages you to look this up and read about them. How can you not love that?This is just such a fun series. It's a shame that it just lasted one season.  Get Voyagers! and travel through history. I can promise that you won't be sorry. This series is fun for all ages, from kids to kids at heart.
Title: N/A

reviewText: You know how when you're talking with your friends and someone says something like, "Hey remember Mushmouth from Fat Albert?"  And you say, "Yeah, that show was cool.  Remember H.R. Puffinstuff or Sigmund and the Sea Monsters?"  And your friends say, "Yeah, that was cool".  But then you catch an episode of Sigmund and the Seamonsters and realize that it was cool when you were seven, and only because they only other thing on at the time were repeats of Bugs Bunny and Road Runner.  I'm not dissing Bugs Bunny or the Road Runner, I'm just saying that you'd seen them a hundred times before, so Sigmund was different.  Not better, just different.Then you are up late one night and Nickelodeon shows a repeat of Sigmund and the Sea Monsters and you think to yourself, "Wow.  Did I really use to watch this?  This is awful."Well, Voyagers isn't awful, but it's not as good as your twelve-year-old brain is telling you it is.
summary: It's OK, but not worth purchasing

reviewText: I am so glad to see this show finally being released on DVD. It was one of my favorite shows back in 1982. It actually makes history fun and interesting. It is also nice to be able to get an official copy of this show instead of resorting to not so clear copies of it from the internet. It doesn't state that there's any extras on this DVD. I was hoping for old interviews of Jon Erik Hexum and Meeno Peluce. Also a current interview with Meeno and his thoughts looking back at the show after all these years would have been nice. Can't wait to get this DVD from Amazon and "go back in time" myself enjoying such a treasure from the past.

reviewText: I really wanted an Omni when I was a kid. Still do I suppose. I bought this out of nostalgia, and while my kids and I enjoyed watching it, we had had enough by the times ran out of episodes. It's good for a trip down memory lane.
summary: Great when I was a kid; as an adult, it's a bit dated
Title: N/A

reviewText: "We travel through time to help history along, to give it a push where it's needed. When the Omni's red, it means history's wrong. Our job is to get history back on track".If you want to learn more about the Omni device, Phineas Bogg and Jeffrey Jones and their excellent adventures traveling through the ages '80s NBC style, take a voyage with Voyagers! - The Complete Series. It's all on DVD!This 4-disc (single-sided) set features all 20 episodes (with episodic promos) in pristine Full Frame (1.33:1) video; English Dolby Digital 2.0 mono audio; English subtitles; plus inspired packaging - a double layer digi-pak tray designed like the Voyagers! guidebook inside a slim outer box. There are chapters for the episodes which you can skip thru using your remote.Despite the lack of extras, Voyagers! - The Complete Series is a DVD set I highly recommend to devoted fans of the show. The show is still fun (and informative) and it looks and sounds great on DVD.
